1.text: Choose fresh flowers that don’t have any morning dew on them.

2.text: Trim the stems to the size that you want for your project.

3.text: Remove low-hanging or scraggly leaves that remain on the stem.

4.text: Cut thick flowers in half so they can be dried flat.

5.text: Store flowers you aren’t ready to use in the fridge for 2-3 days.

6.text: Place the prepared flowers between 2 sheets of parchment paper.

7.text: Set the sheets between the pages of a heavy book.

8.text: Stack on 2 to 3 more books to provide extra weight.

9.text: Leave the flowers alone for 1 to 2 weeks to allow them to dry out fully.

10.text: Buy or cut two 9 by 12 in (23 by 30 cm) pieces of wood.

11.text: Place the prepared flowers between 2 pieces of parchment paper.

12.text: Sandwich the parchment paper between 2 pieces of cardboard.

13.text: Put the cardboard between the 2 pieces of wood.

14.text: Secure each corner of the press together with a c-clamp.

15.text: Let the flowers dry for about 30 days.

16.text: Flatten the flowers with a heavy book to start the pressing process.

17.text: Empty all water from your iron and turn it on to the lowest setting.

18.text: Put the flowers between 2 pieces of parchment paper on the ironing board.

19.text: Hold the iron down on top of the flowers for 10 seconds.

20.text: Let the paper cool completely before you repeat the ironing process.

21.text: Iron the flowers in 10-second increments until all the moisture is gone.

22.text: Assemble a collection of pressed flowers that you’d like to display.

23.text: Wipe down the glass frame to remove any fingerprints or smudges.

24.text: Arrange the flowers before attaching them to the glass.

25.text: Use small pieces of double-sided tape to attach the flowers to the glass.

26.text: Close the frame and hang it up to enjoy your handiwork.
